text: Patient: No. Well some swelling. (pause and ruffling sounds) Doctor: A little bit. No bumps at all up here. No pain, no itching. Patient: No. I noticed some weakness in my right leg. Doctor: They drew blood today. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Last week? Patient: Last week, yes, and my PSA jumped up tremendously. This is from last year. This is December and this is last week – up point five. Doctor: Blood count is good, tab - nothing dramatic – sporadic just below the normal range. So your kidney function goes up and down. So two months hundred at one point six, then it was repeated back down to one and then it was up at one point five. Where did you have your scan last week? Patient: In Hospital A in B___. I have the information and phone number. Doctor: So is G___ a new doctor for you or have you seen him for a while? Patient: No, that was only the second visit. And I saw him after, thoracic surgeon in Hospital B and spotted through tests, prostate cancer cells in my liver, and also on my lung Family Member: December. Patient: And that’s when he recommended I see an oncologist there. He teaches up here, too, so. He’s kind of the go-between. And he’s the one that said he’d work on the lung problem.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Correct. So fifty percent above increase above would be fourteen points. Twenty-eight plus fourteen, that’s forty-two. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So and the PSA is measured every month. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you went on this trial – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - you have a two out of three chance of getting the stereotactic radiotherapy immediately to that lymph node. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or you can have a one out of three chance to get in the observation group first. If you go in the observation group you’re gonna get no additional therapy. You’ll be getting your PSA checked every other month.

text: Patient: I’m doing a lot. Doctor: And, uh, that, we have to be really careful about because I don’t want that to ruin your quality of life. But, I think for the most part, it’s more just gut/GI-ish stuff. So, this lack of appetite, and some people might be, like, “Wow, my stomach actually, you know, doesn’t feel good.” To, “I’ve got diarrhea or nausea.” So, all of that could lead to dehydration. You know, like, we just have to be super on top of that. Patient: Sure. Doctor: To make sure you don’t fall off the grid. Patient: Gotcha. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And it cannot substitute as a weight loss plan. Doctor: Let me just say it for the record. Patient: Well, yeah. We’re working on that part of it. Family Member: Yes. We are.

text: Patient: So I went again back to the emergency hospital and they made a mistake; they pulled it out. I still couldn’t pee. And I had peeing, but very little at the time. So they said it’s not doing it properly, so they put catheter back in. And they told me they shouldn’t have taken out. So the urologist told me; they should have flushed it and anyway, so. Doctor: So they kept you in overnight that time? Patient: Uh no, no. Doctor: So you were only in and out for what time? Patient: Only in and everything was right. There was only one. I came around three-thirty and by eleven you know I’m home. And I felt okay because then when I started peeing again properly there’s no problem anymore. Family Member: They also took; uh they checked the kidneys. Patient: Yeah, they checked the kidneys; the kidneys were improving, but uh - Doctor: So you were in the hospital once or twice? Patient: Twice. Doctor: Overnight? Patient: No. Let’s say over seven days. Doctor: And you were just in E.R. Patient: I was just E.R.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - because up until this point we’ve been talking about you have an invisible cancer. Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: We know that it has recurred; we simply cannot see it or spot it or target that. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Um the reality is that we have tried that in the past and we still do that on occasion in certain patients. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: All the lymph nodes are connected to each other by so-called lymphatic system - Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and so the the the concern about targeting one particular lymph node or maybe two lymph nodes or three lymph nodes is is that um you might only be affecting you know ten percent, fifteen percent, thirty percent of the cancer cells in your body.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Even the PET scan. You know, sensitive but not that sensitive. Patient: Right. Doctor: If it’s just a small amount of cells, but it is enough of a sign for me. Doctor: That’s all of the trials out in the U.S. are now like that. You’re trucking along with Enza, and uh-oh, it’s not working. We slap another medicine on there to see if we can help it. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
